text: [Music]
hey everybody today's kitchen conundrum
is in response to some of the comments
that I've been receiving pastry cream
apparently it's a problem for a lot of
people whether it turns out rainy or the
instructions are complicated I found an
easier way to make pastry cream and it's
so simple it's all in one pot it's a
dump and stir and it's making it so much
faster and even better let me show you
how in a small saucepan here I'm going
to add 1/2 a cup of granulated sugar and
a quarter of a cup of corn starch here
and I'm gonna whisk these two
ingredients together right in the base
of the pot it sits together the
cornstarch which tends to clump up with
the sugar so the sugar particles really
break up the cornstarch and you won't
get any little lumps in your pastry
cream and pastry cream by the way is
that wonderful pudding like filling
that's used in eclairs cream puffs
layered between puff pastry for
Napoleon's and filled in those wonderful
berry tarts it really is one of those
great French all-purpose fillings that's
used in so many different recipes so the
cornstarch and the sugar are completely
sifted together I'm going to add a hefty
pinch of salt which is really important
when you're making sweets to add a
little bit of salt it brings out the
flavor so that's the dry ingredients the
wet ingredients I have two cups of whole
milk I'm gonna add four egg yolks right
to the milk and now typically here with
pastry cream you would temper in hot
milk to the yolks and what tempering
means is bringing up the yolks to the
temperature of the milk that's how you
would normally temper but we're doing it
in a whole new way so we have room
temperature milk and we have room
temperature egg yolks they could even be
cold and you really want to whisk them
together until they're nice and evenly
incorporated here and I'm going to whisk
while I add this milk yolk mixture into
the cornstarch just want to make sure
that you're whisking as you pour so that
no lumps form and now to this I'm gonna
add the butter which is typically
something that you
and at the end of pastry cream but I'm
gonna add it right from the start so
once this is all stirred together a
medium heat and you want the butter to
melt and this mixture will start to
thicken and you have to make sure that
when you're making pastry cream you
actually have to let it boil because
cornstarch is not fully activate unless
it is brought to a boil so the pudding
is nice and thick it's boiling you can
see it's bubbling up and you have to
continue to do this for a full minute
make sure that you are constantly
whisking on this medium heat so it's
been about a minute I'm going to add the
flavoring now I'm using a really good
quality vanilla extract if you wanted to
make this a different flavor you could
absolutely
maybe whisk in some espresso powder if
you wanted it to have a coffee flavor so
now I'm going to strain it through a
fine mesh sieve and this really isn't
necessary at all you can totally skip
this step but what it does do is it just
pulls out any little egg particles that
you may have so just give it a little
bit of a stir in the sieve make sure you
get the bottom side of the sieve because
that's kind of where all of the pastry
cream hides out cover the pastry cream
with plastic wrap and you want to make
sure that you press the plastic wrap
directly on top of the pastry cream this
prevents the pastry cream from forming a
skin while it chills
so the pastry cream is out of the fridge
now like I said before you need to chill
this until it's nice and firm and that
takes about two hours but you can do
this up to two days in advance it's
really great I'm just gonna give this a
stir to kind of break up the pastry
cream a little bit and if you really
wanted a lighter pastry cream you could
fold in a little bit of whipped cream
here that would be fantastic as well I'm
gonna go right into a 9-inch blind-bake
tart shell and using an offset spatula
that's what this thing is called it's an
offset spatula because the handle is
raised just push the pastry cream out to
the edges you don't have to be fancy
here and then one of my favorite things
to do is just to garnish the top with
raspberries and you could be you could
be really picky and finicky and you can
change them like little soldiers all
around but I just like to be a little
bit more organic here and I just kind of
tossed them around the top and they
might think into the filling a little
bit but you can get this right into the
refrigerator chill it too looks nice and
firm and it will slice beautifully what
I like to do is just give it a light
dusting of confectioner's sugar right
over the raspberries and you have a
simple yet elegant dessert with your no
fuss
one pot curdle free pastry cream if you
have any kitchen conundrums that you
need solved write in the comments
section below or reach out to me using
the hashtag kitchen conundrum and I will
solve whatever kitchen problems you may
have
